title: Binomial distribution: A-Level course material
description: This resource introduces the binomial distribution, and how to apply it to solve problems. Topics include a basic introduction, calculating mean and variance, and applying the distribution. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 5 of 12 dealing with statistics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Continuous probability distributions: A-Level course material
description: This resource describes continuous probability distributions, and how to apply them in problem solving. Topics also include calculating mean and variance, and using rectangular distributions. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 7 of 12 dealing with statistics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Algebra II (Eureka Math/EngageNY)
description: Learn Algebra II aligned to the Eureka Math/EngageNY curriculum —polynomials, rational functions, trigonometry, and more.

title: Modelling heat transfer: LearningSpace: Open University
description: This introductory module on the mathematical modelling of heat transfer is the fourth in a series of five modules on mathematical modelling. It is provided as a workbook with a separate document providing answers to the exercises. The module is expected to take four hours to complete and is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016).

title: Desktop applications: getting started
description: This comprehensive, illustrated guide to the basics of using a computer covers the components of a computer, booting up, icons, the taskbar, using a mouse, programs, windows, files and folders, word processing documents, printing, using Microsoft Outlook email, the Internet and shutting down a computer. It includes exercises on files and folders, Microsoft Word, Microsoft Outlook and Internet Explorer. The guide is provided by the IT Services Training team at The University of Manchester, England.
publisher: IT Services Training,The University of Manchester

title: High school level math A&B glossary: English/Burmese: A-C
description: This English-Burmese bi-lingual dictionary of mathematical terms used at high school level is provided by the Office of Bilingual Education, New York State Education Department, USA. This section contains terms where the English word or phrase begins with the letters A-C.
publisher: Office of Bilingual Education, New York State Education Department

title: Determinants 2: Mathematics support materials
description: This resource on the calculation of three by three determinants includes quizzes, exercises and worked examples. It is one of a collection of mathematics support materials provided for schools and colleges by the University of Plymouth School of Mathematics and Statistics.
author: Robin Horan; Martin Lavelle
publisher: School of Mathematics and Statistics, University of Plymouth

title: Role of local institutions in reducing vulnerability to recurrent natural disasters and in sustainable livelihoods development: Philippines: part VII
description: This case study examines the impact of local institutions in the design and implementation of disaster risk management strategies in one vulnerable area in the Philippines. It discusses: the Philippine hazard and disaster situation; disaster risk management activity; the responses of local institutions to several recent typhoons; and an assessment of the role of local institutions in managing recent disasters. This document, Institutions for Rural Development 8, was published by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) in 2006. This section, part 7 of 7, concludes the assessment of institutional response and summarises conclusions and lessons learned. Other sections of this publication are also catalogued in the e-library.
author: Stephan Baas
publisher: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO)

title: Short-term plan of action: Wenchuan earthquake of 12 May 2008
description: This note provides recommendations from The World Bank for the Government of China on short-term actions following the Wenchuan earthquake of 12 May 2008. It is based upon a framework of good practices in recovery and reconstruction after an earthquake. The note covers: a recovery and reconstruction framework; damage and loss assessment; recovery and reconstruction; implementation; and disaster risk reduction. The note is Working Paper Series No. 1, one of a series of EAP DRM KnowledgeNotes on disaster risk management in East Asia and the Pacific. It was published by The World Bank in 2008. This note was prepared for the Government of China as part of a series of good practice notes on post-disaster recovery following the Wenchuan Earthquake that struck on 12 May 2008.
author: Global Facility for Disaster Reduction and Recovery Secretariat

title: Workbook on planning for urban resilience in the face of disasters: adapting experiences from Vietnam's cities to other cities
description: This workbook provides standard procedures local officials can use to develop local resilience action plans (LRAPs) in order to plan for a safer future in urban areas in the face of natural disasters and the consequences of climate change. These cover raising awareness and generating support, the technical analysis, stocktaking and needs assessment, option identification and programme prioritisation, and plan creation and implementation. The workbook is based on the experiences of three cities in Vietnam. Lessons learned when the process was later adopted in cities in the Philippines, China, and Indonesia are also summarised. This document, no.66520, was published by The World Bank in 2012.
author: Fatima Shah; Federica Ranghieri

title: Plate tectonics: LearningSpace: Open University
description: This intermediate module focuses on the theory of plate tectonics. It covers tectonic plates, crustal growth and heat transfer mechanisms, plate boundary types, the difference between relative and true plate motion, and forces influencing plate motion at plate boundaries. The module is expected to take fifteen hours to complete and is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016).

title: Acceptance sampling: A-Level course material
description: This resource describes the theory and application of acceptance sampling. Topics discussed include how various sampling schemes work, selecting the correct plan, and drawing operating characteristic on single and double sampling plans. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 9 of 9 dealing with further concepts in statistics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Analysis of variance (Anova): A-Level course material
description: This resource describes concepts in the analysis of variance (anova). These include: why to analyse data from multiple samples, understanding models of analysis, and carrying out one and two way analysis of variance. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 7 of 9 dealing with further concepts in statistics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Answers: Further statistics: A-Level course material
description: This resource provides the answers to the exercises included in the nine chapters dealing with further concepts in statistics which are contained within the wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. The individual chapters are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Answers: Statistics: A-level course material
description: This resource provides the answers to the exercises included in the 12 chapters dealing with statistics which are contained within the wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. The individual chapters are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Modelling pollution in the Great Lakes: LearningSpace: Open University
description: This introductory module on the mathematical modelling of the variation with time of pollution levels in the Great Lakes of North America is the first in a series of five modules on mathematical modelling. It is provided as a workbook with a separate document providing answers to the exercises. The module is expected to take four hours to complete and is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016).

title: Correlation and regression: A-Level course material
description: This resource provides an introduction to a range of concepts concerning correlation and regression in mathematical samples. Topics include analysis of the relationship between two variables, determining various coefficients such as the product moment correlation coefficient or Spearman's correlation coefficient, and the calculation and use of regression lines. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 12 of 12 dealing with statistics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Data analysis: A-Level course material
description: This resource describes basic concepts in data analysis, such as standard deviation, mean, mode, quartile and median. There is a discussion of different ways to represent data, such as bar or pie charts, the box or whisker plot, frequency diagrams and miscellaneous others. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 16 of 21 dealing with pure mathematics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Data collection: A-Level course material
description: This resource provides an introduction to data collection, discussing concepts such as qualitative and quantitative data, primary and secondary data, and sample collection and analysis. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 2 of 12 dealing with statistics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Descriptive statistics: A-Level course material
description: This resource provides an overview of terminology and techniques used in data presentation. These include frequency and scatter diagrams, calculation of mean, mode, median, quartile and standard deviation values, and related concepts. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 3 of 12 dealing with statistics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Developing modelling skills: LearningSpace: Open University
description: This introductory module on the processes involved in developing mathematical models is the third in a series of five modules on mathematical modelling. It is provided as a workbook with a separate document providing answers to the exercises. The module is expected to take four hours to complete and is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016).

title: Market research methods
description: This resource contains information on a number of market research methods including surveys, questionnaires, qualitative research, in depth interviews, focus groups and transcripts. It is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LabSpace, a collection of open educational resources (OER) available from a wider OER community associated with the Open University.

title: Discrete probability distributions: A-Level course material
description: This resource provides an overview of probability distributions, covering topics such as variance, calculating mean values, uniform distributions, and discrete distributions. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 4 of 12 dealing with statistics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Estimation: A-Level course material
description: This resource forms an introduction to the concept of estimation in assessing probability. Topics covered include the Central Limit Theorem, random sampling, calculating mean and variance values, and working out confidence intervals. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 9 of 12 dealing with statistics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Estimation: A-Level course material
description: This resource describes a number of topics relating to estimation. These include calculating confidence intervals for the mean, variance and standard deviation of a normal distribution, calculating confidence intervals for a proportion, and calculating confidence intervals for the mean of a Poisson distribution. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 2 of 9 dealing with further concepts in statistics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Experimental design: A-Level course material
description: This resource provides an introduction to terms and ideas in experimental design, including error, bias, blocking and replication. Other topics include identifying blind and double blind trials, and understanding the use of control groups. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 6 of 9 dealing with further concepts in statistics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Goodness of fit tests: A-Level course material
description: This resource provides an introduction to using goodness of fit or chi-squared tests to see if sample data are representative of a larger dataset. The resource describes how to calculate expected frequencies for various probability models, and use the chi-squared test to examine sample data. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 5 of 9 dealing with further concepts in statistics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Hypothesis testing: A-Level course material
description: This resource introduces various principles of hypotheses, such as defining and applying null and alternative hypotheses, calculating probabilities using approximate models, and using one or two tailed tests. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 10 of 12 dealing with statistics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Hypothesis testing: One sample tests: A-Level course material
description: This resource introduces various types of hypothesis testing. The topics include one sample t-tests, sign tests and testing hypotheses for normal, binomial or Poisson populations. A range of worked examples is presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 3 of 9 dealing with further concepts in statistics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Hypothesis testing: Two sample tests: A-Level course material
description: This resource provides a description of a range of two sample tests, including how and when to carry out normal or t-tests, performing sign tests on paired samples, and the Wilcoxon signed-rank test. Many worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 4 of 9 dealing with further concepts in statistics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Introduction to qualitative research
description: These notes provide a brief introduction to qualitative research covering qualitative worldviews, theoretical frameworks, conducting qualitative research, and ethical considerations. The notes were written by Tom Lemanski and Tina Overton of the UK Physical Sciences Centre and are made available by the Higher Education Academy, UK.
author: Tom Lemanski; Tina Overton

title: Modelling pollution in the Great Lakes: a review: LearningSpace: Open University
description: This introductory module further develops the mathematical modelling of the variation with time of pollution levels in the Great Lakes of North America and is the fifth in a series of five modules on mathematical modelling. It is provided as a workbook with a separate document providing answers to the exercises. The module is expected to take four hours to complete and is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016).

title: Malaysia: Map: AQUASTAT
description: This map of Malaysia forms part of the AQUASTAT global information system on water and agriculture, provided by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) of the United Nations.

title: How to accelerate your Internet: a practical guide to bandwidth management and optimisation using Open Source software, Chapter 1: Introduction
description: This resource is chapter 1 of a book providing practical information on how to gain the best possible benefit from an Internet connection. It introduces network connections, provides a brief description of various concepts such as bandwidth and latency, and describes some common problems. Other sections of this publication are also catalogued in the e-library.

title: Introduction to real analysis, Supplement II: The method of Lagrange multipliers
description: This document supplements Section 3.4 Improper Integrals of the book Introduction to Real Analysis by Williams F. Trench.
author: William F. Trench

title: Normal distribution: A-Level course material
description: This resource describes normal distributions, and how to use them to solve a wide range of mathematical problems. A discussion of how to apply normal distributions to approximate other types of mathematical distributions is included. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 8 of 12 dealing with statistics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Poisson distributions: A-Level course material
description: This resource introduces the Poisson distribution, its uses and how to apply it. Topics also include calculating mean and variance, combining variables,and approximating a binomial distribution using this method. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 6 of 12 dealing with statistics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Practical guide to the use of selected multivariate statistics
description: Notes are provided on choosing multivariate statistical techniques and the state that data must be in to use the desired technique. They cover data screening, multiple correlation and regression, principle components analysis (PCA) and factor analysis, discriminant analysis, cluster analysis and spatial autocorrelation. Appendices cover correlation coefficients and coefficients of variation, homoscedasticity, linearity, the multivariate general linear hypothesis (MGLH), missing data, multicollinearity and singularity, normality, orthogonality, outliers, residual plots and data transformation. The notes summarise statistical techniques presented in a geography course and are made available online by the Canadian Forest Service, Natural Resources Canada.
author: Mile Wulder

title: Statistical process control: A-Level course material
description: This resource discusses statistical process control and its application. Topics include what the technique is used for, how to set up and interpret charts for a range of statistics, and estimating short-term standard deviation. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 8 of 9 dealing with further concepts in statistics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: How to accelerate your Internet: a practical guide to bandwidth management and optimisation using Open Source software, Glossary
description: This resource is the glossary of a book providing practical information on how to gain the best possible benefit from an Internet connection. It contains definitions of hundreds of terms used in networking and the Internet, laid out in simple, clear language. Other sections of this publication are also catalogued in the e-library.

title: Desktop applications: Microsoft Access 2010 foundation day 1
description: Desktop applications: Access 2010 foundation day 1 is part one of an illustrated training guide that introduces the basic concepts of what a database is, how and why a database should be designed and some of the terminology used. It shows examples of the structure that a typical database takes and the tools utilised to make using a database easier and take the first steps in designing your own database. The course assumes fluent keyboard and mouse skills. The training guide is provided by the IT Services Training team at The University of Manchester, England.
publisher: IT Services Training,The University of Manchester

title: Desktop applications: Microsoft Access 2010 foundation day 2
description: This illustrated training guide follows on from and assumes familiarity from Desktop applications: Microsoft Access 2010 foundation day 1. It provides instructions for the management of Microsoft Access databases and includes guidance on how to backup and save a database, create forms and reports, import data saved in an Excel spreadsheet into a new table and export data in various text formats or for access via the web as a PDF file format. The training guide is provided by the IT Services Training team at The University of Manchester, England.
publisher: IT Services Training,The University of Manchester

title: Desktop applications: Microsoft Access 2010 intermediate day 1
description: This illustrated training guide follows on from the Desktop applications: Access 2010 Foundation Day 1 and Day 2 guides. It is a step-by-step reference guide to some of the further features of Microsoft Access 2010. There is also a follow on from this guide: the Access 2010 Day 2 course. This training guide includes looking at further ways of controlling data entry and ensuring the integrity of the data entered into the tables. Different types of relationships between tables are explored and the guide also examines some of the advanced properties of queries and looks at the various join types. The training guide is provided by the IT Services Training team at The University of Manchester, England.
publisher: IT Services Training,The University of Manchester

title: Desktop applications: Microsoft Access 2010 intermediate day 2
description: This illustrated training guide follows on from Desktop applications: Access 2010 Intermediate day 1. It is a step-by-step reference guide to some advanced features of Microsoft Access 2010. This guide is a companion to the Access 2010 Intermediate Day 2 course. The guide includes some advanced ways of using forms to control data entry and ensuring the integrity of the data entered into the tables. The use of macros to automate tasks in Microsoft Access 2010 will be introduced. This guide will also examine some of the advanced properties of reports.The training guide is provided by the IT Services Training team at The University of Manchester, England.
publisher: IT Services Training,The University of Manchester

title: Desktop applications: Microsoft Excel 2010 foundation day 1
description: Desktop applications: Microsoft Excel 2010 foundation day 1 is part one of a comprehensive illustrated training guide that provides a general introduction to Microsoft Excel 2010. ( A spread sheet program designed for calculations, and charting.) The course assumes good basic keyboard and mouse skills. The course aims to provide readers with a good grasp of how Excel can help with a wide range of basic tasks. The training guide is provided by the IT Services Training team at The University of Manchester, England.
publisher: IT Services Training,The University of Manchester

title: Desktop applications: Microsoft Excel 2010 foundation day 2
description: Desktop applications: Microsoft Excel 2010 foundation day 2 builds on the tasks covered in Excel 2010 Foundation Day 1 and provides additional help on how to make the most of Excel. The course assumes familiarity with the Day 1 material in addition to fluent keyboard and mouse skills. The course aims to provide readers with a good grasp of how Excel can help carry out a range of more complex tasks and how to use the functionality in greater depth. The training guide is provided by the IT Services Training team at The University of Manchester, England.
publisher: IT Services Training,The University of Manchester

title: Desktop applications: Microsoft Excel 2010 intermediate
description: Desktop applications: Microsoft Excel 2010 intermediate is an illustrated training guide that builds on the tasks covered in Excel Foundation and provides additional help in how to make the most of Excel. The course assumes a sound knowledge of basic functions and formulas in addition to very good input skills. The course aims to provide its readers with a good grasp of how Excel can help carry out a range of more complex tasks and how to use the functionality in greater depth. The training guide is provided by the IT Services Training team at The University of Manchester, England.
publisher: IT Services Training,The University of Manchester

title: Desktop applications: Microsoft PowerPoint 2007 foundation day 1 (v1.0)
description: PowerPoint 2007 Foundation 1 (v1.0) is part one of a comprehensive illustrated training guide to the basics of using Microsoft PowerPoint 2007. PowerPoint is a tool to aid in the giving of presentations. Microsoft PowerPoint can also be used for placing presentations online via the web or to create posters. This training guide covers how to: Open and navigate PowerPoint, document management, slide design, colour, working with text and pictures, screen views and printing options. The training guide is provided by the IT Services Training team at The University of Manchester, England.
publisher: IT Services Training,The University of Manchester

title: Desktop applications: Microsoft PowerPoint 2007 foundation day 2 ( v1.0)
description: PowerPoint 2007 Foundation 2 ( v1.0) is part two of a comprehensive illustrated training guide to the basics of using Microsoft PowerPoint 2007. This guide builds on the Microsoft PowerPoint Day 1 and provides additional help in how to make the most of PowerPoint. The course assumes familiarity with the Day 1 material in addition to fluent keyboard and mouse skills. This training guide takes a closer look at the drawing tools and some of the useful features which can help add interest to a presentation. It also provides guidance on how to create graphs and organisation charts. The different animation options are also covered and some brief guidance on how to deliver a presentation. By the end of this course you should have a good grasp of how PowerPoint can help you to carry out a range of more complex tasks and how to use the functionality of PowerPoint in greater depth. The training guide is provided by the IT Services Training team at The University of Manchester, England.
publisher: IT Services Training,The University of Manchester

title: Desktop applications: Microsoft Word 2007 foundation day 1
description: Desktop Applications: Microsoft Word 2007 Foundation Day 1 is part one of a illustrated general introduction to Microsoft Word, a word processing programme designed for its users to manipulate text, type and save documents. (This training guide assumes basic keyboard and mouse skills although some mouse skills are briefly covered.) The guide is aims to give the reader knowledge of how Microsoft Word can help with a wide range of basic tasks and covers how to open, navigate around and close Microsoft Word, document management, saving documents, formatting documents, working with text, keyboard shortcuts, working with pictures, inserting and editing data in documents and tables, printing, security and encryption. The training guide is provided by the IT Services Training team at The University of Manchester, England.
publisher: IT Services Training,The University of Manchester

The course assumes familiarity with the Day 1 material in addition to fluent keyboard and mouse skills. It aims to give the reader a good grasp of how Word can help you to carry out a range of more complex tasks and how to use the functionality of word in greater depth. The training guide is provided by the IT Services Training team at The University of Manchester, England.
publisher: IT Services Training,The University of Manchester

The guide aims to provide the reader with a good grasp of how Word can help to carry out a range of more complex tasks and how to use the functionality of Microsoft word in greater depth.

It includes a preface, a general overview of the book, a list of contributors and credits, and a table of contents. Other sections of this publication are also catalogued in the e-library.

description: This English-Burmese bi-lingual dictionary of mathematical terms used at high school level is provided by the Office of Bilingual Education, New York State Education Department, USA. This section contains terms where the English word or phrase begins with the letters T-Z.
publisher: Office of Bilingual Education, New York State Education Department

title: How to accelerate your Internet: a practical guide to bandwidth management and optimisation using Open Source software, Chapter 2: Policy
description: This resource is chapter 2 of a book providing practical information on how to gain the best possible benefit from an Internet connection. It introduces the idea of setting a network or Internet usage policy, and provides an account of issues encountered at the fictional Havensbury University to illustrate what can happen if usage is not governed. It also includes a sample policy and links to other published examples. Other sections of this publication are also catalogued in the e-library.

title: How to accelerate your Internet: a practical guide to bandwidth management and optimisation using Open Source software, Chapter 3: Monitoring and analysis
description: This resource is chapter 3 of a book providing practical information on how to gain the best possible benefit from an Internet connection. It covers monitoring and usage, and is fairly comprehensive in scope. Topics include IP addresses, monitoring tools, the use of gateways and routers, and describes the hardware used in a network. Other sections of this publication are also catalogued in the e-library.

title: Drug abuse and drug addictions
How to accelerate your Internet: a practical guide to bandwidth management and optimisation using Open Source software, Chapter 4: Implementation
description: This resource is chapter 4 of a book providing practical information on how to gain the best possible benefit from an Internet connection. It covers the practical implementation phase of setting up a network and provides a lot of advice and tips, and examples of good practice. Topics include how to set up firewalls and anti-virus protection. Other sections of this publication are also catalogued in the e-library.

title: How to accelerate your Internet: a practical guide to bandwidth management and optimisation using Open Source software, Chapter 5: Troubleshooting
description: This resource is chapter 5 of a book providing practical information on how to gain the best possible benefit from an Internet connection. It covers common networking problems and troubleshooting issues such as a broken network, network outages, and installing updates. Other sections of this publication are also catalogued in the e-library.

title: How to accelerate your Internet: a practical guide to bandwidth management and optimisation using Open Source software, Chapter 6: Performance tuning
description: This resource is chapter 6 of a book providing practical information on how to gain the best possible benefit from an Internet connection. It focuses on tuning and optimisation, covering topics such as memory optimisation, using caches, authentication systems, and monitoring and fine-tuning Squid software. Other sections of this publication are also catalogued in the e-library.

title: How to accelerate your Internet: a practical guide to bandwidth management and optimisation using Open Source software, Chapter 7: Case studies
description: This resource is chapter 7 of a book providing practical information on how to gain the best possible benefit from an Internet connection. It includes a number of case studies of network implementations, such as the Kenya National Education Network (KENET), Aidworld in Accra, Ghana, and JANET in the UK. Each case study includes details of specific problems and challenges. Other sections of this publication are also catalogued in the e-library.

title: How to accelerate your Internet: a practical guide to bandwidth management and optimisation using Open Source software, Chapter 8: The future
description: This resource is chapter 8 of a book providing practical information on how to gain the best possible benefit from an Internet connection. It provides a summary of potential future developments in networking, such as new software and trends in developing countries. Other sections of this publication are also catalogued in the e-library.

title: ICTs: device to device communication: LearningSpace: Open University
description: This introductory module examines communication networks and how devices talk to each other. It covers signals, wired and wireless networks, smart homes and RFID (Radio Frequency Identity). The module is expected to take 20 hours to complete and is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016).

title: Intermediate school level mathematics glossary: English/Burmese
description: This bi-lingual English-Burmese dictionary of mathematical terms used at middle school level is provided by the Office of Bilingual Education, New York State Education Department, USA.
publisher: Office of Bilingual Education, New York State Education Department

title: Answers: Discrete mathematics: A-Level course material
description: This resource provides the answers to the exercises included in the 15 chapters dealing with discrete mathematics which are contained within the wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. The individual chapters are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Divergence and curl: Mathematics support materials
description: This resource on the calculation of divergence and curl in vector calculus includes quizzes, exercises and worked examples. It is one of a collection of mathematics support materials provided for schools and colleges by the University of Plymouth School of Mathematics and Statistics.
author: Robin Horan; Martin Lavelle
publisher: School of Mathematics and Statistics, University of Plymouth

title: Introduction to data and information: LearningSpace: Open University
description: This introductory module examines how a computer processes data and converts it to information. It covers computers in daily life, data and information, maps and the GPS (Global Positioning System), search engines and finding information, genetic databases and disease, art and the computer, computers as controllers, and selling on the Web. The module is expected to take twenty hours to complete and is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016).

title: Introduction to HTML
description: This resource introduces the fundamental tags required to get started with the HTML mark-up language. It covers: HTML and XHTML; the structure on an HTML document; hypertext links; including images; converting existing HTML documents to XHTML; cascading style sheets (CSS); style properties for text; and, HTML editors and utilities. It is an open educational resource (OER) from the University of Leicester.
author: Richard Mobbs

title: Introduction to UNIX
description: This resource introduces the fundamental commands required to get started with the UNIX operating system. It covers: UNIX commands; the UNIX filing system; and, UNIX file management. It is an open educational resource (OER) from the University of Leicester.
author: Richard Mobbs

title: Living with the internet: keeping it safe: LearningSpace: Open University
description: This introductory module focuses on using the Internet safely. It covers viruses, worms, Trojans, patches, anti-virus software, firewalls, hoaxes, spam, adware and spyware, cookies and other security issues. The module is expected to take ten hours to complete and is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016).

title: Living with the internet: learning online: LearningSpace: Open University
description: This introductory module focuses on the safe use of computers and the skills and learning styles required to use a computer for online learning. The module is expected to take four hours to complete and is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016).

title: Using a computer for study: LearningSpace: Open University
description: This introductory module covers the use of a computer for study. It focuses on communicating (email and chat), and participation in online conferences. The module is expected to take six hours to complete and is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016).

title: Finding information in education: LearningSpace: Open University
description: This introductory module covers the identification and use of information resources in education. The module covers: different types of resources and how to search for and use them; evaluating Internet resources; organising information; and keeping up to date. It is aimed at both students and teachers and requires access to the Internet to fully benefit from the material. Some of the Web links in the module are no longer working. The module is expected to take nine hours to complete and is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016).

title: Finding information in mathematics and statistics: LearningSpace: Open University
description: An introduction to finding and using mathematical information. Topics covered include use of bibliographic databases, using the Internet to locate information, producing bibliographies, and using a variety of information sources such as electronic journals and newsfeeds. Access to the Internet is required to fully benefit from this resource. This introductory module is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016). It is expected to take nine hours to complete.

title: Finding information in science and nature: LearningSpace: Open University
description: This introductory module provides guidance on finding and using information in science and nature. A self-assessment exercise is followed by notes on searching for, evaluating and organising information. It covers search engines and gateways, books and e-books, databases, images, journals, encyclopaedias, news and Internet resources. Access to the Internet is required to fully benefit from this module. Some of the links are no longer working. The module is expected to take nine hours to complete and is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016).

title: ICTs: technology news: LearningSpace: Open University
description: This introductory module examines the use of the Internet as a tool for keeping up-to-date. It covers the study skills required, such as taking notes and summarising and also examines different learning skills. Brief guidance is given on evaluating Web resources. Netiquette and ethical and legal considerations are also discussed. The module requires access to the Internet to fully benefit from the material. Some of the Web links in the module are no longer working. The module is expected to take eight hours to complete and is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016).

title: Information on the web: LearningSpace: Open University
description: This introductory module covers the skills required to use search engines to find information and images on the Internet, and also how to critically assess and reference the resources that are found. Some of the exercises require Web access. Some of the Web links in the module are no longer working. The module is expected to take fifteen hours to complete and is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016).

title: Web guide: LearningSpace: Open University
description: This introductory module provides guidance on using the Internet, including Web browsers, websites, use of favourites, home pages, pop up windows, assessing the quality of Web pages, using the Internet safely PDFs, accessibility and language settings. Useful tips and tricks are also provided. The module requires access to the Internet to fully benefit from the material. Some of the Web links in the module are no longer working. The module is expected to take six hours to complete and is provided by the UK Open University as part of its OpenLearn, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at June 2016).

title: Elementary school level mathematics glossary: English/Burmese
description: This bi-lingual English-Burmese dictionary of mathematical terms used at primary school level is provided by the Office of Bilingual Education, New York State Education Department, USA.
publisher: Office of Bilingual Education, New York State Education Department

title: A Ratazana
description: A ratazana do mato visitou a ratazana doméstica para ver como ela tinha uma boa vida. No entanto,  a ganância da ratazana doméstica levou a melhor e a ratazana do mato aprendeu a dar valor à sua casa.
author: Translators without Borders

title: High school level math A&B glossary: English/Burmese: D-I
description: This English-Burmese bi-lingual dictionary of mathematical terms used at high school level is provided by the Office of Bilingual Education, New York State Education Department, USA. This section contains terms where the English word or phrase begins with the letters D-I.
publisher: Office of Bilingual Education, New York State Education Department

title: High school level math A&B glossary: English/Burmese: I-P
description: This English-Burmese bi-lingual dictionary of mathematical terms used at high school level is provided by the Office of Bilingual Education, New York State Education Department, USA. This section contains terms where the English word or phrase begins with the letters I-P.

title: High school level math A&B glossary: English/Burmese: P-T
description: This English-Burmese bi-lingual dictionary of mathematical terms used at high school level is provided by the Office of Bilingual Education, New York State Education Department, USA. This section contains terms where the English word or phrase begins with the letters P-T.
publisher: Office of Bilingual Education, New York State Education Department

title: Elementary linear algebra
description: This book includes linear equations, matrices, subspaces, determinants, complex numbers, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, identifying second degree equations and three-dimensional geometry. Solutions to the exercises are available in a separate document.
author: K. R. Matthews

title: Learning a second language: LearningSpace: Open University
description: This masters-level module focuses on how students learn to make meaning through learning additional languages. The module explores the differences between learning first and second languages, and covers the application of scaffolding in an EFL classroom. It is aimed at teachers and educators and is expected to take four hours to complete. The module is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016).
author: Maria Leedham

title: Sentence structure
description: Guidance is given on types and structures of sentences in written English. This is one of a series of grammar guides provided by Learning Development at the University of Leicester to help students improve their writing skills.

title: Using paragraphs
description: Guidance is given on how to use paragraphs in written English. This is one of a series of grammar guides provided by Learning Development at the University of Leicester to help students improve their writing skills.

title: Using the apostrophe
description: Guidance is given on how to use the apostrophe in written English. This is one of a series of grammar guides provided by Learning Development at the University of Leicester to help students improve their writing skills.

title: Using the comma
description: Guidance is given on how to use the comma in written English. This is one of a series of grammar guides provided by Learning Development at the University of Leicester to help students improve their writing skills.

title: Using the semi-colon and colon
description: Guidance is given on how to use the colon and the semi-colon in written English. This is one of a series of grammar guides provided by Learning Development at the University of Leicester to help students improve their writing skills.

title: Abstract algebra: theory and applications
description: This book contains integers, groups, cyclic groups, permutation groups, cosets and Lagrange's Theorem, introduction to cryptography, algebraic coding theory, isomorphisms, normal subgroups and factor groups, homomorphisms, matrix groups and symmetry, structure of groups, group actions, the Sylow Theorems, rings, polynomials, integral domains, lattices and Boolean algebras, vector spaces, fields, finite fields and Galois theory
author: Thomas W. Judson

title: Algebra: Economics fact & formulae
description: A simple guide to algebra, comprising examples of removing brackets, the formula for solving quadratic equations, laws of indices, and laws of logarithms. Examples of proportions and percentages are also included. The resource forms 1 of 5 fact sheets on maths for economics produced by mathcentre.

title: Algebra: Facts & formulae
description: A basic introduction to algebra, comprising the formula for solving a quadratic equation, laws of indices, laws of logarithms, the formula for change of base, and partial fractions. The resource forms 1 of 11 general maths fact sheets produced by mathcentre.

title: Algebra: Mathematics for chemistry facts and formulae
description: A basic introduction to algebra for chemists, comprising the formula for solving a quadratic equation, laws of indices, laws of logarithms, determining pH, the formula for change of base, inequalities, and sigma notation. The resource forms 1 of 11 mathematics for chemistry fact sheets produced by mathcentre.

title: Unit 8: Data sets and distribution
Algebraic fractions: Mathematics support materials
description: This resource on algebraic fractions includes quizzes, exercises and worked examples covering the addition of algebraic fractions and simple partial fractions. It is one of a collection of mathematics support materials provided for schools and colleges by the University of Plymouth School of Mathematics and Statistics.
author: Robin Horan; Martin Lavelle
publisher: School of Mathematics and Statistics, University of Plymouth

title: Analysis of functions of a single variable
description: This book contains real and complex numbers, the limit of a sequence of numbers, functions and continuity, differentiation and local behaviour, integration and average behaviour, integration over smooth curves in the plane, the fundamental theorem of algebra and the fundamental theorem of analysis.
author: Lawrence W. Baggett

title: Elements of abstract and linear algebra
description: This book contains chapters on the background and fundamentals of mathematics, groups, rings, matrices and matrix rings and linear algebra.
author: E. H. Connell

title: Extending algebra: A-Level course material
description: This resource provides a description of how to solve complicated equations using advanced algebraic concepts such as polynomials, the remainder theorem, and factorisation. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 6 of 21 dealing with pure mathematics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Factorising expressions: Mathematics support materials
description: This resource on factorising simple algebraic expressions includes quizzes, exercises and worked examples. It is one of a collection of mathematics support materials provided for schools and colleges by the University of Plymouth School of Mathematics and Statistics.
author: Robin Horan; Martin Lavelle
publisher: School of Mathematics and Statistics, University of Plymouth

title: Fractions: Mathematics support materials
description: This resource on the addition, multiplication and division of fractions includes quizzes, exercises and worked examples. It is one of a collection of mathematics support materials provided for schools and colleges by the University of Plymouth School of Mathematics and Statistics.
author: Robin Horan; Martin Lavelle
publisher: School of Mathematics and Statistics, University of Plymouth

title: Functions of a complex variable: More facts & formulas
description: This resource provides definitions of a number of terms relating to the functions of a complex variable. Topics include the derivative, Cauchy-Riemann equations, singularities, the Laurent series, poles and residues. The resource forms 1 of 13 advanced maths for engineers fact sheets produced by mathcentre.

title: Functions: A-Level course material
description: This resource describes the use of functions to solve mathematical problems. Specific topics discussed include composite functions, determining and applying the inverse of a function, and using graphs to display them. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 3 of 21 dealing with pure mathematics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Functions: Mathematics support materials
description: This resource on functions includes quizzes, exercises and worked examples covering flow diagrams for functions, composite functions, and inverse functions. It is one of a collection of mathematics support materials provided for schools and colleges by the University of Plymouth School of Mathematics and Statistics.
author: Robin Horan; Martin Lavelle
publisher: School of Mathematics and Statistics, University of Plymouth

title: Geometric group theory
description: Lecture notes on geometric group theory are provided, covering free groups, presentations, group actions on trees, graphs of groups and groups as geometric objects. The notes were prepared to accompany a course given by Panos Papazoglou at the Mathematical Institute, University of Oxford, England.
author: Panos Papazoglou

title: Gradients and directional derivatives: Mathematics support materials
description: This resource on the calculation of gradients and directional derivatives in vector calculus includes quizzes, exercises and worked examples. It is one of a collection of mathematics support materials provided for schools and colleges by the University of Plymouth School of Mathematics and Statistics.
author: Robin Horan; Martin Lavelle
publisher: School of Mathematics and Statistics, University of Plymouth

title: Mathematical Analysis: Volume I
description: This book contains set theory, real numbers and fields, vector spaces and metric spaces, function limits and continuity and differentiation and antidifferentiation.

title: Elementary calculus: an infinitesimal approach, Chapter 2: Differentiation
description: This book includes chapters on real and hyperreal numbers, differentiation, continuous functions, integration, limits, analytic geometry and approximations, applications of the integral, trigonometric functions, exponential and logarithmic functions, infinite series, vectors, partial differentiation, multiple integrals, vector calculus and differential equations.
author: H. Jerome Keisler

title: Elementary calculus: an infinitesimal approach, Chapter 7: Trigonometric functions
description: This book includes chapters on real and hyperreal numbers, differentiation, continuous functions, integration, limits, analytic geometry and approximations, applications of the integral, trigonometric functions, exponential and logarithmic functions, infinite series, vectors, partial differentiation, multiple integrals, vector calculus and differential equations.
author: H. Jerome Keisler

title: Graph transforms: A-Level course material
description: This resource provides a description of various transforms that can be applied to functions. Topics include how to build complex functions by combining simple ones, and predicting how a graph will change when transforms are applied. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 4 of 21 dealing with pure mathematics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Graphs of common functions: Economics fact & formulae
description: This document provides simple examples of the graphs of linear, exponential, quadratic and logarithmic functions. The resource forms 1 of 5 fact sheets on maths for economics produced by mathcentre.

title: Graphs of common functions: Facts & formulae
description: A guide to basic graphs for linear functions, the equation of a circle, quadratic functions, and the modulus and unit step functions. The resource forms 1 of 11 general maths fact sheets produced by mathcentre.

title: Graphs of common functions: Mathematics for chemistry facts and formulae
description: A guide to the graphs of straight line, exponential, logarithmic and quadratic functions. The resource also includes some basic statistics terms, such as variance and standard deviation. such as The resource forms 1 of 11 mathematics for chemistry fact sheets produced by mathcentre.

title: Graphs of common functions: Mathematics for computer science facts and formulae
description: This sheet provides graphs of exponential and logarithmic functions, and functional growth. The resource forms 1 of 11 mathematics for computer science fact sheets produced by mathcentre.

title: Group theory
description: Lecture notes on group theory are provided, covering an introduction to group theory, Abelian groups, prime numbers in finite group theory, soluble groups, character theory and simple groups. An appendix covers groups of order less than 16. The notes were prepared to accompany a course given by Michael Collins at the Mathematical Institute, University of Oxford, England.
author: Jan E Grabowski

title: Groups and group actions
description: Lecture notes on groups and group actions are provided, covering group axioms, permutation groups, sub-groups and cyclic groups, equivalence relations, and Lagrange's Theorem. The notes were prepared to accompany a course given by Richard Earl at the Mathematical Institute, University of Oxford, England.
author: Richard Earl

title: Growth and decay: A-Level course material
description: This resource describes how to express growth and decay models mathematically, using exponential functions and logarithms. Topics include solving equations using logarithms and how to differentiate both exponential and logarithmic functions. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 11 of 21 dealing with pure mathematics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Hyperbolic functions: A-Level course material
description: This resource provides a description of hyperbolic functions and associated applications, such as finding derivatives and integrals, applying inverse hyperbolic functions, and recognising logarithmic equivalents. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 2 of 9 dealing with further pure mathematics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Hyperbolic functions: Facts & formulae
description: An introduction to, and examples of, hyperbolic functions, hyperbolic identities, and inverse hyperbolic functions. The document also contains the Greek alphabet as a reference. The resource forms 1 of 11 general maths fact sheets produced by mathcentre.

title: Inequalities: A-Level course material
description: This resource describes inequalities in mathematical problems, and how to recognise and apply them in problem solving. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 4 of 15 dealing with discrete mathematics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Scale of cells
description: Thinking about how large a cell is compared to viruses, proteins and simple molecules.

title: Inequalities: Mathematics support materials
description: This resource on inequalities and their solution includes quizzes, exercises and worked examples. It is one of a collection of mathematics support materials provided for schools and colleges by the University of Plymouth School of Mathematics and Statistics.
author: Robin Horan; Martin Lavelle
publisher: School of Mathematics and Statistics, University of Plymouth

title: Inquiry-based introduction to proofs
description: This book includes number theory, sets, functions and relations, infinity and Peano axioms. Answers to the exercises are available in a separate document.

title: Inquiry-based introduction to proofs: answers to exercises
description: This document includes answers to the exercises that can by found in the book Inquiry-Based Introduction to Proofs by Jim Hefferon (which includes number theory, sets, functions and relations, infinity and Peano axioms).

title: Introduction to fields
description: Lecture notes are provided on fields, covering characteristics of fields, the degree of a field extension, algebraic elements of extension fields, a geometric application, roots of polynomials, roots of unity, multiple roots of polynomials and finite fields. An appendix provides a summary of knowledge required to study this course (axioms for fields, elementary algebra, elementary number theory, ring theory, Gauss's Lemma and Eisenstein's Criterion. The notes were prepared to accompany a course given by Peter M. Neumann at the Mathematical Institute, University of Oxford, England.

title: Introduction to matrices: Mathematics support materials
description: This resource on matrices includes quizzes, exercises and worked examples covering addition and subtraction, transposition, and basic row operations. It is one of a collection of mathematics support materials provided for schools and colleges by the University of Plymouth School of Mathematics and Statistics.
author: Robin Horan; Martin Lavelle
publisher: School of Mathematics and Statistics, University of Plymouth

title: Introduction to vectors and tensors: linear and multilinear algebra, Volume 1
description: This book (in two volumes) contains chapters on elementary matrix theory; sets, relations and functions; groups, rings and fields; vector spaces; linear transformations; determinants and matrices; spectral decompositions; tensor algebra and exterior alge...

title: Introduction to vectors: Mathematics support materials
description: This resource on vectors includes quizzes, exercises and worked examples covering vector addition and component form. It is one of a collection of mathematics support materials provided for schools and colleges by the University of Plymouth School of Mathematics and Statistics.
author: Robin Horan; Martin Lavelle
publisher: School of Mathematics and Statistics, University of Plymouth

title: Iteration: A-Level course material
description: An introduction to the concept of iteration and iterative methods in solving mathematical problems. This resource requires a basic understanding of algebra and simple differentiation. Topics also include using both numerical and graphical methods to solve equations. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 19 of 21 dealing with pure mathematics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Language, notation and formulas: LearningSpace: Open University
description: This resource describes the appropriate language to use when dealing with mathematical problems and solutions. Topics include how to use mathematical symbols and notation, the use of word formulas, unit conversion, and how to set out and label mathematical problems. This introductory module is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016). It is expected to take five hours to complete.

title: Lie algebras
description: This book on Lie algebras covers: the Campbell Baker Hausdorff Formula; sl(2) and its representations; the classical simple algebras; Engel-Lie-Cartan-Weyl; the conjugacy of Cartan sub-algebras; simple finite dimensional algebras; cyclic highest weight modules; Serre's theorem; Clifford algebras and spin representations; the Kostant Dirac operator; and the centre of U(g). The book was written by Shlomo Sternberg from the Department of Mathematics, Harvard University, USA.

These chapters cover applications to differential equations and the simple paradigm from E to E.

description: This book on linear algebra and infinite dimensional spaces includes chapters about decomposition for matrices, transformations in inner-product spaces, the Gerschgorin Circle Theorem, convergence, orthogonality, projections, orthonormal vectors, the finite dimensional paradigm, bounded linear maps, differential equations, adjoint operators, compact sets, compact operators, the Eigenvalue problem, normal operators, the Fredholm alternative theorems, closed operators and approximation in a Hilbert space. title: Linear algebra, infinite dimensions, and Maple, Chapter 17: The Eigenvalue problem and Chapter 18: Normal operators and the more general paradigm
description: This book on linear algebra and infinite dimensional spaces includes chapters about decomposition for matrices, transformations in inner-product spaces, the Gerschgorin Circle Theorem, convergence, orthogonality, projections, orthonormal vectors, the finite dimensional paradigm, bounded linear maps, differential equations, adjoint operators, compact sets, compact operators, the Eigenvalue problem, normal operators, the Fredholm alternative theorems, closed operators and approximation in a Hilbert space. title: Linear algebra, infinite dimensions, and Maple, Chapter 19: Compact operators & orthonormal families and Chapter 20: A characterisation of compact operators
description: This book on linear algebra and infinite dimensional spaces includes chapters about decomposition for matrices, transformations in inner-product spaces, the Gerschgorin Circle Theorem, convergence, orthogonality, projections, orthonormal vectors, the finite dimensional paradigm, bounded linear maps, differential equations, adjoint operators, compact sets, compact operators, the Eigenvalue problem, normal operators, the Fredholm alternative theorems, closed operators and approximation in a Hilbert space. title: Linear algebra, infinite dimensions, and Maple, Chapter 1: Decomposition for matrices and Chapter 2: Exp(tA)

description: This resource on log-log plots (the use of logarithms to plot graphs of data that is changing by a power law) includes quizzes, exercises and worked examples. title: Mathematical language: LearningSpace: Open University
description: An introduction to a range of basic terms and concepts used in mathematics. The resource is divided into four key areas: sets and set notation; functions; mathematical proofs; and identities (binomial theorem, geometric series identity, and the polynomial factorisation theorem). This intermediate module is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016). It is expected to take 20 hours to complete.

title: Matrices and transformations: A-Level course material
description: This resource provides a detailed study of matrices and transformations. The topics covered include: using matrix and vector algebra, determining matrix inverses, using matrices to express simple and more complex transformations, apply properties of invariancy to describe transformations, and deriving eigenvalues and eigenvectors. Many worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 9 of 9 dealing with further pure mathematics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.
publisher: Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching (CIMT), University of Plymouth

title: Maxima and minima: Mathematics support materials
description: This resource on the use of differentiation to determine the maxima and minima of functions includes quizzes, exercises and worked examples. author: Robin Horan; Martin Lavelle
publisher: School of Mathematics and Statistics, University of Plymouth

title: Modelling displacements and velocities: LearningSpace: Open University
description: An introduction to the use of vectors and vector conversion, covering topics such as coverting vectors from geometric to component form (and vice versa), using bearings to describe direction, the difference between speed and velocity, and expressing displacements and velocities in geometric form. This introductory module is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016). It is expected to take three hours to complete.

title: Modelling with Fourier series: LearningSpace: Open University
description: This resource describes the use of partial differential equations to model waves and heat transfer; some basic prerequsitie knowledge of such equations is required. The module shows how to determine simple initial and boundary conditions, solve wave equations, and find the coefficients of a Fourier series. This intermediate module is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016). It is provided as a workbook with a separate document providing answers to the exercises and is expected to take 16 hours to complete.

title: Numbers, units and arithmetic: LearningSpace: Open University
description: This is a short introduction to the basics of arithmetic, using positive and negative numbers, fractions and decimals in simple problem solving. The aim is to be able to solve a range of basic problems without using a calculator. This introductory module is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016). It is expected to take five hours to complete.

title: Numbers: an introduction to subtraction: LearningSpace: Open University
description: A very short introduction to techniques used in subtraction, including whole numbers and decimals. The module should take around one hour to complete. The module is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016).

title: Numbers: getting to grips with division: LearningSpace: Open University
description: A very short (one hour) introduction to simple division, using both whole numbers and decimals. The module is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016).

title: Numbers: LearningSpace: Open University
description: This resource describes real numbers and their properties. Topics include the relationship between real numbers and recurring decimals, irrational numbers and numeric inequalities. The use of the Triangle Inequality, the Binomial Theorem and the Least Upper Bound Property are all described .This intermediate module is provided by the UK Open University as part of its LearningSpace, a collection of over 800 free online courses (as at July 2016). It is expected to take 20 hours to complete.

title: Properties of curves: A-Level course material
description: This resource covers advanced properties of curves. Topics include: locating key points on a graph, discovering asymptotes to a curve, identifying restricted regions, curves of functions, and deriving the equations of tangents, normals and chords. Numerous worked examples are presented, with illustrations where applicable. The resource is chapter 8 of 9 dealing with further pure mathematics, as part of a wider collection of A-Level course material provided by the Centre for Innovation in Mathematics Teaching, University of Plymouth. Answers to the exercises are also catalogued in the e-library.

description: This resource introduces the use of codes in everyday life, with topics including the use of check digits, understanding different code designs, and examples such as bar codes, postcodes, Braille, and telephone numbers. title: Contact: Lecture 8: Elasticity and plasticity
description: Lecture notes on contact between two elastic solid bodies are provided, covering elastic strings, other thin solids, and smooth contact in plane strain. title: Forces 1: Mechanics facts & formulae
description: A basic description of several key terms relating to forces. These include: weight, reaction, and tension relating to both inelastic and elastic systems. The resource forms 1 of 11 mechanics fact sheets produced by mathcentre.

description: A description of the forces present in friction, with examples and illustrations provided. The resource forms 1 of 11 mechanics fact sheets produced by mathcentre.
